items.title: Hope to support an api like auto_parse(time_str)
items.body:
## Feature Request
Hope to support an  api like auto_parse(time_str)

when i use arrow in web spider project, i hava to parse the datetime string to a datetime object, and do other handle. but the datetime string always like '2018-05-14',  '2018-05-4',  '2018-05-14', 'Mar, 05, 2020', 'February 2020', '2020-08-17 00:20'...,so i hope to have an api like auto_parse(time_str) to parse out all kinds of time strings.

items.title: Could not parse timezone expression "PDT"
items.body:
## Issue Description

I'm sure I'm doing something wrong, but I only see three timezone parsing options available to me (ZZZ, ZZ, and Z) and none of them seem to work.  I believe ZZZ is the correct one to use, but it complains.

What's the proper way of parsing the PDT timezone?

```
In [2]: arrow.get("Mon, 10 Aug 2020 22:00:12 -0700 (PDT)", "ddd, DD MMM YYYY HH:mm:ss Z (ZZZ)")

    576         if tzinfo is None:
    577             raise ParserError(
--> 578                 'Could not parse timezone expression "{}"'.format(tzinfo_string)
    579             )
    580

ParserError: Could not parse timezone expression "PDT"
```

FYI, this is a date that gmail's IMAP is handing me in my email messages.

## System Info

macOS 10.15.5 (19F101)
Python 3.7.6
arrow==0.15.8

items.title: Consider handling incomplete dates and times
items.body:
## Feature Request

In our project working on plain texts, we encounter many dates like "2017-05", "August 3rd", which contains only partly information. When I do `arrow.get("2017-05")`, it would be `<Arrow [2017-08-01T00:00:00+00:00]>`. The lack of day is handled by adding a default value to be "01", and we even could not know it was originally incomplete.

But we want the "lack of information" to be preserved, so that we could decide how to deal with it later. Maybe we just throw the incomplete dates away, maybe we want it to set another default value like 15th, maybe we do some calculation and get the correct day, and fill up the incomplete date to be a complete one.

I wonder if arrow could handle such problems. Thank you!

items.title: AttributeError: module 'arrow' has no attribute 'FORMAT_RFC3339'
items.body:
## Issue Description
Hi there, I'm trying to use the code from the documentation, but get this weird error

> AttributeError: module 'arrow' has no attribute 'FORMAT_RFC3339'

```python
import arrow
utc = arrow.utcnow()
print(utc.format(arrow.FORMAT_RFC3339))
```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: module 'arrow' has no attribute 'FORMAT_RFC3339'
```

## System Info

- 🖥  macOS 10.15.1
- 🐍 Python 3.7.7
- 🏹 0.15.6

items.title: Extend parse_iso to accept '2020-06-10 14:33:23.489 +0200'
items.body:
<!--
Thanks for taking the time to submit this feature request.

Please provide us with a detailed description of the
potential improvement. Happy feature requesting 💡!
-->

## Feature Request

I would like 
```
arrow.get('2020-06-10 14:33:23.489 +0200')
```
To work. For now it doesn't like the second space. It would be easy for me to fix this but it kind of looks like this is something that should work. 

I understand that it might not be striclty ISO 8601 compliant but the following comment suggest that the function is a bit more inclusive:
https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/blob/0a37fa5643ed2a0fe7714854fc3d91644fc8fb4e/arrow/parser.py#L115

items.title: Parsing ms and us int/float timestamps in arrow.get
items.body:
## Issue Description

Reading the docs, I should be able to supply a timestamp in milliseconds or microseconds, formatted as an int or float. When I pass a millisecond timestamp, I get ValueError - it only seems to work with seconds.

Expected:
```
>>> arrow.get(1590889920000.0).timestamp
1590889920000
```

Actual:
```
>>> arrow.get(1590889920000.0).timestamp
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/charlie/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/arrow/api.py", line 21, in get
    return _factory.get(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/charlie/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/arrow/factory.py", line 176, in get
    return self.type.fromtimestamp(arg, tzinfo=tz)
  File "/Users/charlie/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/arrow/arrow.py", line 161, in fromtimestamp
    dt = datetime.fromtimestamp(float(timestamp), tzinfo)
ValueError: year 52383 is out of range
```

## System Info

- 🖥 **OS name and version**: OS X 10.15.4
- 🐍 **Python version**: 3.7.6
- 🏹 **Arrow version**: 0.15.6

items.title: Consider shipping tox.ini with package
items.body:
Since `python setup.py test` is now deprecated we should think about adding our tox.ini to releases.

https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/1684
https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/5534

items.title: Comparing Arrow objects
items.body:
Is there currently a way to compare arrow objects? For example if I wanted to check if arrow object A was later or earlier than arrow object B?

I'm working on another issue where that functionality would be super helpful, wasn't sure if I was missing something.

items.title: Problem with building - running Tox commands
items.body:
I followed the commands I saw in comment thread - installing Tox and then running the tox -e 37 command (the tox command alone gave a lot of environment errors) and there were a ton of issues, but here is the summary:

![Screen Shot 2020-04-09 at 6 57 32 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23154272/78947660-ff495a80-7a93-11ea-94d4-b965c911910f.png)

items.title: Add common format strings
items.body:
<!--
Thanks for taking the time to submit this feature request.

Please provide us with a detailed description of the
potential improvement. Happy feature requesting 💡!
-->

## Feature Request

<!-- Replace with a description of the potential improvement. -->

Pendulum has a nice feature that allows you to make a function call on a Pendulum object to automatically get a pre-formatted, common string (e.g. a cookie time string). See this page for examples: https://pendulum.eustace.io/docs/#common-formats.

items.title: Replace class setup functions with Pytest fixtures
items.body:
Since we recently refactored the tests to use Pytest, it would be nice to convert the existing unittest-style setup/teardown class functions into Pytest-style fixtures. This would lead to better maintainability and compatibility going forward.

An example of the `setup_class(cls)` code that should be replaced: https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/blob/master/tests/test_factory.py#L17

items.title: Unable to handle YYYY/M
items.body:
I am going through a list of publications with the help of arrow, some of the dates of which are registered as YYYY/M. Arrow raises a ParserError because this format is not supported. 

I've resolved it locally by including YYYY/M and YYYY-M in the parser.py format (row 133 onwards).

items.title: humanize granularity doesn't behave as expected
items.body:
## Issue Description

I'd like to use humanize() to print out human (engineer)-readable durations for a potentially long-running data processing pipeline I'm working on.  

For my pipeline, the useful precision for duration output depends on how long a given run takes to execute, and can span seconds to hours.  I'd settled on seconds as a useful metric for logging approximate runtime, but humanize() doesn't seem to be giving me the expected output when I add the granularity argument.

````
>> import arrow
>> now = arrow.utcnow()
>> mins = now.shift(seconds=-200)
>>> mins.humanize(now, only_distance=True)
'3 minutes'
>>> mins.humanize(now, only_distance=True, granularity="second")
'seconds'
````

I'd expected the final statement to ideally evaluate to "3 minutes 20 seconds", or at least to "200 seconds".  If "granularity" is intended to convey a seconds remainder, e.g. in this case of "3 minutes 20 seconds" the output should still be "20 seconds".   It's also worth noting that I thought the documentation on the granularity argument could use some fleshing out to disambiguate cases like i've mentioned here.


## System Info

- 🖥 **OS name and version**: alpine3.9
- 🐍 **Python version**: Python 3.7.3 -->
- 🏹 **Arrow version**: 0.15.4

items.title: Please don't remove the deprecation warning mitigation!
items.body:
Hi, in one of my libraries I was suppressing the `ArrowParseWarning` warning, with plans to remove it once Arrow 0.15 came out. Well, just now I updated things only to find that when the warning stopped being emitted, the class was also removed entirely — breaking all software that was importing it for the purpose of suppressing the warning (i.e. dying with an `ImportError`).

It would have been nice if, instead of removing it outright, it remained as a stub class so that people could remove the warning suppression on their own schedule rather than having to pin library versions and so on.

Now that Arrow 0.15 is out I'll be updating my library that uses Arrow, but it would have been nice if I didn't need to do this.

items.title: Add support for humanizing a rate
items.body:
I found myself needing to humanize a rate, like "2.1 events per second". I wrote a function that does this for English:

```py
def natural_rate(delta: Union[float, datetime.timedelta]):
    """return an english string representing a rate. delta is assumed to be a rate as "1 per delta"."""
    if isinstance(delta, datetime.timedelta):
        delta = delta.total_seconds()
    rate = 1 / delta
    for i, multiplier in enumerate((1, 60, 60, 24, 7)):
        rate *= multiplier
        if rate > 1:
            break
    duration = ('second', 'minute', 'hour', 'day', 'week')[i]
    return f'{rate:.2g} per {duration}'
```

However it would be really nice if arrow supported this with locale translation.

items.title: Specify number of subsecond tokens to parse
items.body:
Currently when parsing strings with a subsecond component the following works.

```shell
>>> arrow.get("2013-02-09T11:09:23.345678", "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.SSS")
<Arrow [2013-02-09T11:09:23.345678+00:00]>
```

But it doesn't actually matter how many `S` tokens you supply, all the subseconds are parsed.
```shell
>>> arrow.get("2013-02-09T11:09:23.345678", "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.S")
<Arrow [2013-02-09T11:09:23.345678+00:00]>
```

We thought about removing the ability to pass multiple S tokens in 0.15.0 but decided to avoid changing anything in that release. The formatter will let you specify how ever many S tokens you need.

Community thoughts would be useful here.


Should be:

items.title: Make .get() handle string tzinfo kwarg properly
items.body:
With the way factory.get() is currently setup the following happens;

```shell
>>> import arrow
>>> arrow.get(tzinfo='EST')
<Arrow [2019-08-01T18:30:24.799081+00:00]>
```

Essentially .get() is ignoring the tzinfo kwarg if it's not a tzinfo object and just returning .utcnow(). This could produce hard to detect errors imo, I think it should raise an error if the tzinfo kwarg is unused. Since we allow str tzinfo's elsewhere it makes sense to do so here.

@jadchaar any thoughts?

items.title: v0.15.0 Changes❗
items.body:
In the upcoming version 0.15.0 of `arrow`, we will be making a lot of changes to the behavior of `arrow.get()` to address a number of reported parsing bugs. We have outlined the changes below:

# Fixes
- Most instances of `arrow.get()` returning an incorrect arrow object from a partial parsing match have been eliminated.

For example,

```python
>>> arrow.get("garbage2017everywhere")
<Arrow [2017-01-01T00:00:00+00:00]>
```

```python
>>> arrow.get('Jun-2019', ['MMM-YY', 'MMM-YYYY'])
<Arrow [2020-06-01T00:00:00+00:00]>
```

These will raise a ParserError in 0.15.0.

- When a meridian token (a|A) is passed and no meridians are available for the specified locale (e.g. unsupported or untranslated), a ParserError is raised.
- Timestamp strings are no longer supported in the `arrow.get()` method without a format string:  `arrow.get("1565358758")`. This change was made to support the ISO 8601 basic format and to address bugs such as https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/447.

The following will still work as expected: 

```python
arrow.get("1565358758", "X")
arrow.get("1565358758.123413", "X")
arrow.get(1565358758)
arrow.get(1565358758.123413)
```

- The timestamp token (`X`) will now matches float timestamps: `arrow.get("1565358758.123415", "X")`.
- The timestamp token (`X`) will now only match on strings that strictly contain integers and floats, preventing incorrect matches.

# New Features

- ISO-8601 basic format style is now supported (e.g.  `YYYYMMDDThhmmssZ`)
- Added support for DDD and DDDD ordinal date tokens (e.g. `"1998-045"`)

# Issues addressed

- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/560
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/538
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/434
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/519
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/91
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/447
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/196
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/456
- https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/issues/396

# Development progress

You can view the progress of these changes here: https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/tree/Version-0.15.0.

# Disable Warnings

To get rid of the ArrowParseWarning messages in 0.14.3 onwards, do the following:

```python
import warnings
from arrow.factory import ArrowParseWarning

warnings.simplefilter("ignore", ArrowParseWarning)
```

items.title: "a" token for am/pm is not being processed in get() when using Spanish locale
items.body:
I have been parsing some dates in Spanish and found out that the [`a` token](https://arrow.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#tokens) for am/pm does not get applied with the locale `es`.

See for example this date in English. It gets parsed properly by doing 8 pm -> 20 h.

```
>>> arrow.get('June 30, 2019 - 08:00 pm', "MMMM DD, YYYY - hh:mm a")                                          
<Arrow [2019-06-30T20:00:00+00:00]>
```

However, in Spanish it does not work:

```
>>> arrow.get('Junio 30, 2019 - 08:00 pm', "MMMM DD, YYYY - hh:mm a", locale="es")                            
<Arrow [2019-06-30T08:00:00+00:00]>
```

In fact, anything can be put in the `a` token!

```
>>> arrow.get('Junio 30, 2019 - 08:00 pasdfasdfm', "MMMM DD, YYYY - hh:mm a", locale="es")                    
<Arrow [2019-06-30T08:00:00+00:00]>
```

items.title: setup.py is trying to import dependencies which aren't yet installed
items.body:
In this recent change (https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/commit/2e5031b473bcf10b99b9d7ff8a7e72499c412c07), setup.py now does `from arrow import __version__` which triggers a bunch of other imports. This fails if `python-dateutil` hasn't already been installed.

items.title: Transition testing framework from nose/chai to pytest
items.body:
`nose` and `chai` are not regularly updated anymore, so a transition to [nose2](https://docs.nose2.io/en/latest/) or [pytest](https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/) would be wise to explore.

For now, `nose` and `chai` seem to play fine with Python 2.7 through Python 3.8, but that could easily change in the future.

items.title: Change Sphinx documentation theme
items.body: The F6 theme that [we are currently using](https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/tree/master/docs/_themes) for the docs does not seem to be maintained anymore and does not play well with modern web standards (e.g. responsiveness on screen resizing). Therefore, I think it is worth it to explore a transition to a more modern and maintained theme such as the [default alabaster theme](https://alabaster.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) in Sphinx.

items.title: Display stdlib errors on Travis run
items.body:
So I figured out how we can display `stdlib` errors on a Travis run: we can run `nose` as a module and set a flag (`-Wd`)for Python to display all warnings.

I was thinking we could make a separate target for testing the dev releases:
```make
test-dev:
	rm -f .coverage
	. local/bin/activate && local/bin/python3 -Wd -m nose
```

_Originally posted by @jadchaar in https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/pull/585#issuecomment-493787621_

Hi there,

Suggestions: 
1.

2. 
If I could supply `,"D/M/YY$"` I'd have a lot more confidence that the string will be correctly processed, regardless of where the pattern exists in the list. 

3. 
If YY is specified, it strictly looks for YY. If the pattern extends without a delimiter, it's treated as invalid and the pattern is skipped.


Please let me know if you need any more information here!
Cheers,
Adam

items.title: Publish .whl file to PyPI
items.body:
Being a pure python library and containing the `[bdist_wheel]` attribute in `setup.cfg` this library is already ready to generate .whl files which are the [preferred packaging format](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0427/). Currently, arrow is my only dependency that doesn't publish a wheel file to PyPI and this creates some deployment complications for some serverless frameworks (namely Azure). Since the file can be generated as simply as
```
python setup.py sdist bdist_wheel
```
it would be good to have this library on the list at https://pythonwheels.com/.

items.title: Interactive demo for `arrow` code examples
items.body:
Hello @crsmithdev,

I've been using `arrow` lately and found it really interesting. We're also evaluating to include it in our curriculum at https://rmotr.com/ (co-founder and teacher here). It's cool to show `arrow` (and also other libraries) in comparison to the built-in `datetime` module.

While looking at the code examples in the README file I thought it would be great to provide some interactive demo that people can use to play with the library before committing to download and install it locally.

items.title: DST conversion: EDT to EST happens at UTC time but not at local time
items.body:
According to the [Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone), the time returns at 2:00 a.m. EDT to 1:00 a.m. EST on the first Sunday in November. On November 4th, 2018, I observed that the time isn't set back at the correct time.
```python
import arrow

just_before = arrow.get('2018-11-04T01:59:59.999999')
print(just_before)  # prints 2018-11-04T01:59:59.999999+00:00
just_after = just_before.shift(microseconds=1)
print(just_after)   # prints 2018-11-04T02:00:00+00:00

just_before_eastern = just_before.replace(tzinfo='US/Eastern')
print(just_before_eastern)  # prints 2018-11-04T01:59:59.999999-04:00
just_after_eastern = just_after.replace(tzinfo='US/Eastern')
print(just_after_eastern)   # prints 2018-11-04T02:00:00-05:00
```
The tzinfo is set back from `-04:00` to `-05:00` on November 4th, 02:00 UTC, which is November 3rd, 22:00 EDT.
Not sure if it may be a feature (UTC used as switch time for simplicity or consistency?). But logically it makes all the sense to switch from EDT to EST at proper local time, November 4th, 02:00. Which, in UTC, is November 4th, 06:00. 
If we replace just_before in the code above to `arrow.get('2018-11-04T05:59:59.999999')`, the line with 'US/Eastern' timezone prints `-05:00` already in just_before_eastern, which is incorrect.

items.title: microsecond precision simulation?
items.body:
I'm not sure this is a good idea, but, on Windows, with Python 3.6 at least, there is no microsecond precision on Python's implementation of datetime.datetime.utcnow(), and as a result, Arrow also doesn't have that precision, so on Linux/OSX, this works, but on Windows, it doesn't:

```
arrow1 = arrow.utcnow()
arrow2 = arrow.utcnow()
if arrow1 == arrow2:
  print("Sad and busted on Windows")
else:
  print("Yay! Linux microsecond precision!")
```

In order to make timestamps linear, I've made a function that adds an ever increasing number:

```
last_unix_timestamp = time.time()

def linear_utc_now():
    global last_unix_timestamp
    this_unix_timestamp = time.time()
    if this_unix_timestamp <= last_unix_timestamp:
        this_unix_timestamp = last_unix_timestamp + 0.000001
    last_unix_timestamp = this_unix_timestamp
    this_arrow = arrow.get(this_unix_timestamp)
    return this_arrow
```

It generates 100000 arrows in 347ms, while arrow.utcnow() generates 100000 in 207ms, so there's a performance hit.

I'm not sure if it's a good idea to add this to arrow, but I thought I'd open it as an issue and if you guys wanted it, it's yours.

items.title: humanize has odd behavior with future days
items.body:
example:
```python3
import arrow

print(arrow.utcnow().shift(days=1).humanize())
print(arrow.utcnow().shift(days=2).humanize())
print(arrow.utcnow().shift(days=3).humanize())

print(arrow.utcnow().shift(days=4).humanize())
```

```
in a day
in 2 days
in 2 days
in 3 days
in 3 days
```

it seems the humanizer trips over after 2 days - after that it's one day behind every time.

looking into the code, the second delta is always one off being the right number of days.

for example the seconds delta between now and +3days is `259199`, making the delta `259200` seems to fix the problem

    1483272000
    1483293600
    2017-01-01 12:00:00

Note that the arrow's `timestamp` attribute and the `strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')` output is the same regardless of the system timezone, which I'd expect: arrows are UTC by default. But the output of `strftime('%s')` varies by system timezone, which I did *not* expect. I would expect it to always be the same as the `timestamp` attribute.

After noticing this in arrow I checked and in fact the bug exists in Python's own datetime, for aware datetime instances: I filed that as [Python bug 32988](https://bugs.python.org/issue32988). So if arrow is just handing `strftime` duties off to `datetime` behind the scenes, this is essentially the same as that bug, I guess. Still figured it'd be worth reporting.

items.title: tzinfo is ignored in arrow.get() with time string
items.body:
The `tzinfo` parameter doesn't seem to do anything when calling `arrow.get`, at least with a time string in the form of `YYYY-MM-DD mm:ss`:
```
In: arrow.get('2018-01-29 14:46', tzinfo='US/Central')
Out: <Arrow [2018-01-29T14:46:00+00:00]>

In: arrow.get('2018-01-29 14:46', tzinfo=pytz.timezone('US/Central'))
Out: <Arrow [2018-01-29T14:46:00+00:00]>
```

The constructed arrow ends up with the wrong timezone (utc) as shown above.

Is there another way to do this?  Or at least a way to replace the timezone of the arrow object without affecting the time? This workaround does the job, but kinda defeats the purpose of using `arrow`:
```
In: arrow.get(pytz.timezone('US/Central').localize(arrow.get('2018-01-29 14:46').datetime.replace(tzinfo=None)))
Out: <Arrow [2018-01-29T14:46:00-06:00]>
```

items.title: Conditioning install_requires against sys.version_info does not work for wheels
items.body:
If python3 is used to build a wheel, the `if sys.version_info[0] < 3:` (in [setup.py](https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow/blob/master/setup.py#L30)) would be `False`. The built wheel cannot be used for python2 while, unfortunately, pip does not distinguish py2/py3 wheel.

Instead, `extras_require` should be the option here to put predicates that would be evaluated during runtime (instead of build time). An example is how [websocket-client does this type of task](https://github.com/websocket-client/websocket-client/blob/master/setup.py#L17); also [this blog explains](https://hynek.me/articles/conditional-python-dependencies/).

items.title: Using granularity in humanize causes it to ignore only_distance
items.body:
Example:
```
>>> import arrow
>>> now = arrow.utcnow()
>>> then = now.shift(hours=-5)
>>> now.humanize(other=then, only_distance=True, granularity='hour')
'in 5 hours'
>>> now.humanize(other=then, only_distance=True)
'5 hours'
```
I expected both to return `5 hours`

Tested on 0.12.0 from pip in both python 2.7.12 and python 3.6.3.
